Audiences in Shakespeare's time were more accustomed than modern playgoers to actors having longer stage time. Modern translators tend to simplify the sentence structures of earlier dramas, which included compound sentences with intricate hierarchies of subordinate clauses.
Chinese literature.
In translating Chinese literature, translators struggle to find true fidelity in translating into the target language. In "The Poem Behind the Poem", Barnstone argues that poetry "can't be made to sing through a mathematics that doesn't factor in the creativity of the translator".
A notable piece of work translated into English is the "<a href="Wen%20Xuan">Wen Xuan</a>", an anthology representative of major works of Chinese literature. Translating this work requires a high knowledge of the <a href="genre">genre</a>s presented in the book, such as poetic forms, various prose types including memorials, letters, proclamations, praise poems, edicts, and historical, philosophical and political disquisitions, threnodies and laments for the dead, and examination essays. Thus the literary translator must be familiar with the writings, lives, and thought of a large number of its 130 authors, making the "Wen Xuan" one of the most difficult literary works to translate.
Sung texts.
Translation of a text that is sung in vocal music for the purpose of singing in another language—sometimes called "singing translation"—is closely linked to translation of poetry because most vocal music, at least in the Western tradition, is set to <a href="Verse%20%28popular%20music%29">verse</a>, especially verse in regular patterns with <a href="rhyme">rhyme</a>. (Since the late 19th century, musical setting of <a href="prose">prose</a> and <a href="free%20verse">free verse</a> has also been practiced in some <a href="art%20music">art music</a>, though popular music tends to remain conservative in its retention of <a href="stanza">stanza</a>ic forms with or without <a href="refrain">refrain</a>s.) A rudimentary example of translating poetry for singing is church <a href="hymn">hymn</a>s, such as the German <a href="chorale">chorale</a>s translated into English by <a href="Catherine%20Winkworth">Catherine Winkworth</a>.
Translation of sung texts is generally much more restrictive than translation of poetry, because in the former there is little or no freedom to choose between a versified translation and a translation that dispenses with verse structure. One might modify or omit rhyme in a singing translation, but the assignment of syllables to specific notes in the original musical setting places great challenges on the translator. There is the option in prose sung texts, less so in verse, of adding or deleting a syllable here and there by subdividing or combining notes, respectively, but even with prose the process is almost like strict verse translation because of the need to stick as closely as possible to the original prosody of the sung melodic line.
Other considerations in writing a singing translation include repetition of words and phrases, the placement of rests and/or punctuation, the quality of vowels sung on high notes, and rhythmic features of the vocal line that may be more natural to the original language than to the target language. A sung translation may be considerably or completely different from the original, thus resulting in a <a href="contrafactum">contrafactum</a>.
Translations of sung texts—whether of the above type meant to be sung or of a more or less literal type meant to be read—are also used as aids to audiences, singers and conductors, when a work is being sung in a language not known to them. The most familiar types are translations presented as subtitles or <a href="surtitles">surtitles</a> projected during <a href="opera">opera</a> performances, those inserted into concert programs, and those that accompany commercial audio CDs of vocal music. In addition, professional and amateur singers often sing works in languages they do not know (or do not know well), and translations are then used to enable them to understand the meaning of the words they are singing.
Religious texts.
An important role in history has been played by translation of religious texts. Such translations may be influenced by tension between the text and the religious values the translators wish to convey. For example, <a href="Buddhist">Buddhist</a> <a href="monk">monk</a>s who translated the <a href="India">India</a>n <a href="sutra">sutra</a>s into <a href="Chinese%20language">Chinese</a> occasionally adjusted their translations to better reflect <a href="China">China</a>'s distinct <a href="culture">culture</a>, emphasizing notions such as <a href="filial%20piety">filial piety</a>.
One of the first recorded instances of translation in the West was the 3rd century BCE rendering of some books of the biblical <a href="Old%20Testament">Old Testament</a> from Hebrew into <a href="Koine%20Greek">Koine Greek</a>. The translation is known as the "<a href="Septuagint">Septuagint</a>", a name that refers to the supposedly seventy translators (seventy-two, in some versions) who were commissioned to translate the Bible at <a href="Alexandria">Alexandria</a>, Egypt. According to legend, each translator worked in solitary confinement in his own cell, and, according to legend, all seventy versions proved identical. The "Septuagint" became the <a href="source%20text">source text</a> for later translations into many languages, including Latin, <a href="Coptic%20language">Coptic</a>, <a href="Armenian%20language">Armenian</a>, and <a href="Georgian%20language">Georgian</a>.
Still considered one of the greatest translators in history, for having rendered the Bible into Latin, is <a href="Jerome">Jerome</a> (347–420 CE), the <a href="patron%20saint">patron saint</a> of translators. For centuries the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Roman Catholic Church</a> used his translation (known as the <a href="Vulgate">Vulgate</a>), though even this translation stirred controversy. By contrast with Jerome's contemporary, <a href="Augustine%20of%20Hippo">Augustine of Hippo</a> (354–430 CE), who endorsed precise translation, Jerome believed in adaptation, and sometimes invention, in order to more effectively bring across the meaning. Jerome's colorful Vulgate translation of the Bible includes some crucial instances of "overdetermination". For example, <a href="Isaiah">Isaiah</a>'s prophecy announcing that the Savior will be born of a virgin, uses the word "'almah", which is also used to describe the dancing girls at <a href="Solomon">Solomon</a>'s court, and simply means young and nubile. Jerome, writes <a href="Marina%20Warner">Marina Warner</a>, translates it as "virgo", "adding divine authority to the virulent cult of <a href="sex">sex</a>ual disgust that shaped Christian moral theology (the [Moslem] "<a href="Quran">Quran</a>", free from this linguistic trap, does not connect <a href="Maryam%20%28name%29">Mariam</a>/<a href="Mary%2C%20mother%20of%20Jesus">Mary</a>'s miraculous nature with moral horror of sex)." The apple that <a href="Eve">Eve</a> offered to <a href="Adam">Adam</a>, according to Mark Polizzotti, could equally well have been an <a href="apricot">apricot</a>, orange, or banana; but Jerome liked the <a href="pun">pun</a> "malus/malum" (apple/evil).
<a href="Pope%20Francis">Pope Francis</a> has suggested that the phrase "lead us not into temptation", in the <a href="Lord%27s%20Prayer">Lord's Prayer</a> found in the <a href="Gospel%20of%20Matthew">Gospels of Matthew</a> (the first Gospel, written c. 80–90 CE) and <a href="Gospel%20of%20Luke">Luke</a> (the third Gospel, written c. 80–110 CE), should more properly be translated, "do not let us fall into temptation", commenting that God does not lead people into temptation—<a href="Satan">Satan</a> does. Some important early Christian authors interpreted the Bible's Greek text and <a href="Jerome">Jerome</a>'s <a href="Latin%20Vulgate">Latin Vulgate</a> similarly to Pope Francis. A.J.B. Higgins in 1943 showed that among the earliest Christian authors, the understanding and even the text of this devotional verse underwent considerable changes. These ancient writers suggest that, even if the Greek and Latin texts are left unmodified, something like "do not let us fall" could be an acceptable English rendering. Higgins cited <a href="Tertullian">Tertullian</a>, the earliest of the Latin <a href="Church%20Fathers">Church Fathers</a> (c. 155–c. 240 CE, "do not allow us to be led") and <a href="Cyprian">Cyprian</a> (c. 200–258 CE, "do not allow us to be led into temptation"). A later author, <a href="Ambrose">Ambrose</a> (C. 340–397 CE), followed Cyprian's interpretation. <a href="Augustine%20of%20Hippo">Augustine of Hippo</a> (354–430), familiar with Jerome's Latin Vulgate rendering, observed that "many people... say it this way: 'and do not allow us to be led into temptation.'"
In 863 CE the brothers <a href="Saints%20Cyril%20and%20Methodius">Saints Cyril and Methodius</a>, the <a href="Byzantine%20Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>'s "Apostles to the Slavs", began translating parts of the Bible into the <a href="Old%20Church%20Slavonic">Old Church Slavonic</a> language, using the <a href="Glagolitic%20script">Glagolitic script</a> that they had devised, based on the <a href="Greek%20alphabet">Greek alphabet</a>.
The periods preceding and contemporary with the <a href="Protestant%20Reformation">Protestant Reformation</a> saw translations of the Bible into <a href="vernacular">vernacular</a> (local) European languages—a development that contributed to <a href="Western%20Christianity">Western Christianity</a>'s split into Roman Catholicism and <a href="Protestantism">Protestantism</a> over disparities between Catholic and Protestant renderings of crucial words and passages (and due to a Protestant-perceived need to reform the Roman Catholic Church). Lasting effects on the religions, cultures, and languages of their respective countries were exerted by such Bible translations as <a href="Martin%20Luther">Martin Luther</a>'s into German (the <a href="New%20Testament">New Testament</a>, 1522), <a href="Jakub%20Wujek">Jakub Wujek</a>'s into Polish (1599, as revised by the <a href="Jesuits">Jesuits</a>), and <a href="William%20Tyndale">William Tyndale</a>'s (New Testament, 1526 and revisions) and the "<a href="King%20James%20Version">King James Version</a>" into English (1611).
Efforts to translate the Bible into English had their <a href="martyr">martyr</a>s. <a href="William%20Tyndale">William Tyndale</a> (c. 1494–1536) was convicted of <a href="heresy">heresy</a> at <a href="Antwerp">Antwerp</a>, was strangled to death while tied at the stake, and then his dead body was burned. Earlier, <a href="John%20Wycliffe">John Wycliffe</a> (c. mid-1320s – 1384) had managed to die a natural death, but 30 years later the <a href="Council%20of%20Constance">Council of Constance</a> in 1415 declared him a heretic and decreed that his works and earthly remains should be burned; the order, confirmed by <a href="Pope%20Martin%20V">Pope Martin V</a>, was carried out in 1428, and Wycliffe's corpse was exhumed and burned and the ashes cast into the <a href="River%20Swift">River Swift</a>. Debate and religious <a href="schism">schism</a> over different translations of religious texts continue, as demonstrated by, for example, the <a href="King%20James%20Only%20movement">King James Only movement</a>.
A famous "mistranslation" of a <a href="Biblical">Biblical</a> text is the rendering of the Hebrew word ("keren"), which has several meanings, as "horn" in a context where it more plausibly means "beam of light": as a result, for centuries artists, including sculptor <a href="Michelangelo">Michelangelo</a>, have rendered <a href="Moses">Moses the Lawgiver</a> with horns growing from his forehead.
Such fallibility of the translation process has contributed to the <a href="Islamic">Islamic</a> world's ambivalence about translating the "<a href="Quran">Quran</a>" (also spelled "Koran") from the original Arabic, as received by the prophet <a href="Muhammad">Muhammad</a> from <a href="Allah">Allah</a> (God) through the angel <a href="Gabriel">Gabriel</a> incrementally between 609 and 632 CE, the year of Muhammad's death. During prayers, the "Quran", as the miraculous and inimitable word of Allah, is recited only in Arabic. However, as of 1936, it had been translated into at least 102 languages.
A fundamental difficulty in translating the "Quran" accurately stems from the fact that an Arabic word, like a Hebrew or Aramaic word, may have a <a href="Polysemy">range of meanings</a>, depending on <a href="Context%20%28language%20use%29">context</a>. This is said to be a linguistic feature, particularly of all <a href="Semitic%20languages">Semitic languages</a>, that adds to the usual similar difficulties encountered in translating between any two languages. There is always an element of human judgment—of interpretation—involved in understanding and translating a text. Muslims regard any translation of the "Quran" as but one possible interpretation of the <a href="Classical%20Arabic">Quranic (Classical) Arabic</a> text, and not as a full equivalent of that divinely communicated original. Hence such a translation is often called an "interpretation" rather than a translation.
To complicate matters further, as with other languages, the meanings and usages of some expressions have changed "over time", between the Classical Arabic of the "Quran", and modern Arabic. Thus a modern Arabic speaker may misinterpret the meaning of a word or passage in the "Quran". Moreover, the interpretation of a Quranic passage will also depend on the historic context of Muhammad's life and of his early community. Properly researching that context requires a detailed knowledge of "<a href="hadith">hadith</a>" and "<a href="Prophetic%20biography">sirah</a>", which are themselves vast and complex texts. Hence, analogously to the translating of <a href="%23Chinese%20literature">Chinese literature</a>, an attempt at an accurate translation of the "Quran" requires a knowledge not only of the Arabic language and of the target language, including their respective evolutions, but also a deep understanding of the two <a href="culture">culture</a>s involved.
Experimental literature.
Experimental literature, such as <a href="Kathy%20Acker">Kathy Acker</a>’s novel "Don Quixote" (1986) and <a href="Giannina%20Braschi">Giannina Braschi</a>’s novel "<a href="Yo-Yo%20Boing%21">Yo-Yo Boing!</a>" (1998), features a translative writing that highlights discomforts of the interlingual and translingual encounters and literary translation as a creative practice. These authors weave their own translations into their texts.
Acker's <a href="Postmodern%20literature">Postmodern</a> fiction both fragments and preserves the materiality of <a href="Catullus">Catullus</a>’s Latin text in ways that tease out its semantics and syntax without wholly appropriating them, a method that unsettles the notion of any fixed and finished translation.
Whereas Braschi's trilogy of experimental works ("<a href="Empire%20of%20Dreams%20%28poetry%20collection%29">Empire of Dreams</a>", 1988; "<a href="Yo-Yo%20Boing%21">Yo-Yo Boing!</a>", 1998, and "<a href="United%20States%20of%20Banana">United States of Banana</a>", 2011) deals with the very subject of translation. Her trilogy presents the evolution of the Spanish language through loose translations of dramatic, poetic, and philosophical writings from the Medieval, <a href="Spanish%20Golden%20Age">Golden Age</a>, and <a href="Modernismo">Modernist</a> eras into contemporary Caribbean, Latin American, and Nuyorican Spanish expressions. Braschi’s translations of classical texts in Iberian Spanish (into other regional and historical linguistic and poetic frameworks) challenge the concept of national languages.
Science fiction.
<a href="Science%20fiction">Science fiction</a> being a <a href="genre">genre</a> with a recognizable set of conventions and literary genealogies, in which language often includes <a href="neologism">neologism</a>s, neosemes, and <a href="invented%20languages">invented languages</a>, techno-scientific and <a href="Pseudoscience">pseudoscientific</a> vocabulary, and fictional representation of the translation process, the translation of science-fiction texts involves specific concerns. The science-fiction translator tends to acquire specific competences and assume a distinctive publishing and cultural agency. As in the case of other mass-fiction genres, this professional specialization and role often is not recognized by publishers and scholars.
Translation of science fiction accounts for the transnational nature of science fiction's repertoire of shared conventions and <a href="Trope%20%28literature%29">tropes</a>. After <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, many European countries were swept by a wave of translations from the English. Due to the prominence of English as a source language, the use of <a href="pseudonym">pseudonym</a>s and <a href="pseudotranslation">pseudotranslation</a>s became common in countries such as Italy and Hungary, and English has often been used as a <a href="vehicular%20language">vehicular language</a> to translate from languages such as Chinese and Japanese.
More recently, the international market in science-fiction translations has seen an increasing presence of source languages other than English.
Technical translation.
<a href="Technical%20translation">Technical translation</a> renders documents such as manuals, instruction sheets, internal memos, minutes, financial reports, and other documents for a limited audience (who are directly affected by the document) and whose useful life is often limited. Thus, a user guide for a particular model of refrigerator is useful only for the owner of the refrigerator, and will remain useful only as long as that refrigerator model is in use. Similarly, software documentation generally pertains to a particular software, whose applications are used only by a certain class of users.
